text:
SEBASTIAN: You see
things that are so
depressing all over the place.

And then, every once in awhile,
you see these little pockets
of good things.

And CNN Heroes is
one of those pockets.
[music playing]

BRIAN O'CONNOR: CNN
Heroes is absolutely

helping me to mold my little
buddies in fifth grade

into the type of
teenagers and adults
that we all want them to be.

SEBASTIAN: Mr. O'Connor is
definitely know for CNN Heroes.
It's like his thing.
It's so much fun.
It's empowering.

I mean, they're
all great people.

And it just has like a positive
impact on everyone in the room.
-Never, ever quit.

BRIAN O'CONNOR: I'm
so happy and so proud

when my former
students come back

and the first thing they want to
do is talk about the CNN Heroes

and how it's still
inspiring them.

SARAH: The feeling
of wanting to help

people was definitely sparked
by Mr. O'Connor's class.

Before that, I had never really
thought about giving back.

There was a realization of
my own potential and power.

And I have been volunteering at
a daycare for almost five years
now.
SEBASTIAN: We saw this hero.

And he modified houses
to help veterans
get around more easily.
And that inspire me.

So, for my birthday,
people that really know
me donate to a veterans' cause.

SARAH: Giving back
makes me feel awesome.

Helping people is
something I'd want
to do for the rest of my life.

BRIAN O'CONNOR: CNN Heroes
makes me a better teacher.

Let's try to bring some of that
everywhere we go and pay it

forward to everybody we cross
paths with because that's only

going to make our situation
and their situation
that much better, OK?

-It makes you feel good
to be able to help people.

BRIAN O'CONNOR: The
CNN Heroes are giving

us the most valuable
lessons that you
would want any kid to have.
[kids shouting "thank you"]
[whooshing]
